response: Garden Fresh Box is a great option, an affordable box of produce once monthly with many convenient pick up locations. In addition there is the Farmers Market on Ontario open on Saturdays in Sarnia all year, Petrolia until October and the market by the bay on Sundays until late September.  There are also local farms with reasonable prices: ie. Zekfelds

I do see my self as a localvore.  I believe that it is is important to eat fresh fruits and vegetables for my health.  I also believe that purchaing locally produced produce strengthens the local food system.  It helps to provide options that will disappear if local producers can't find a market.

Other (explain in your comment)\nThis is hard one.  You need to find ways to increase the demand or the produce that local farmers can produce.  That means you need shop at dam markets and encourage other to do the same.  When you go out to eat you need to ask if there are any items on the menu that include local products.  Institutional food prepare in your community's hospitals, schools soup kitchens. churches, meals on wheels need to be encouraged to buy from local producers.There should be labels in all of the market that identify the locally produced products.  More produce needs to be in the convenience stores.

In my experience, anytime you can connect what is going on in your community to the classroom there are big benefits.   First the student realize the they are studying something that is real.   When it comes to food I would venture that most students are interested in FOOD.The more connections that can be made to understanding the local economy and how it relates to food production and consumption the more that you can learn about the impacts of food choices, the types of food sources and the impact of food on their own health and well being, the more they will be interested.
I am  Out of the area so I don't have any input on this challenge.

I know of a few really great Community Gardens  One is called Harvest for the Hungry.  It has been running for decades in Santa Rosa, CA.  They grow food to give away!Another Great Community Garden is the Posh Squash.  It is located at the Sea Ranch, CA.  The efforts are self supporting and supply food to the actual gardeners supplying the labor to the garden.I think that some of the most important type of support is free access to the land and then the next most important is the clarity of purpose, and ensuing organizational structure to enable it to thrive.

I believe that it would be in the best interest of the County to find ways to promote and distribute information about all of the sources for local produce available in her neighborhood.  You might need to use radio or TV or other means to drive interested people to a website thaws dedicated to providing this information.  You could partner with the local papers and the local producers to fund the adverting  as a local benefit to the community.

No, all kinds of people buy locally sourced foods.  The type of individual who buys local is a motivated and knowledgeable consumer, and one with a vested interest in their health and the well-being of the community.  I am that kind of a person - my husband and I have a farm background, and we like to support local farmers.  I also am a mother of 4 children, and tend to cook from scratch, for the best flavour, cost, and healthiness.  I don't buy pre-made meals like lasagne.  I cook meat bones to make homemade stock, and we don't use cake mixes, for example.  However, the cost of food and the need for convenience also factor into our purchases.

In retail her hours are probably all over the place so she may not be able to get there regularly.  It's also a nuisance to make sure you have enough cash when you go.  It's hard to do a weeks worth of shopping as you are soon laden down with more than you can carry, which means several trips back and forth to the car.  Speaking of the car, on market days it can be a nightmare driving and parking there.  There are still some items you may want but can't get there, so there's still a trip to the supermarket to be made.  In the end she will end up at the supermarket.  I guess what I'm saying is, there needs to be one place, open daily, with carts, debit, and parking.

Not the lowest income bracket, because you need transportation to buy local foods. Getting to the market is not as hard as getting home when you don't have a car.I'm not sure other than that - I buy local and have my whole life. My mom cans and preserves, and we grew up with that in our house. My whole family buys ingredients for canning from farmers and markets, I think because of how we were raised. Apples, potatoes, pears, leeks, eggs, from the market, and tomatoes, peppers, herbs, hot peppers, peas, beans, etc., we've picked from local farms. But we were also raised to eat in season, which means oranges in the winter not peppers, celery in the fall and not the spring, and not much salad in January.

Locally sourcing the majority of school cafeteria food\nA consistent market is what is needed for local producers. By-laws enforcing stores to sell local foods goes against all economic reasoning. Think of last year - no apples. Then what?However, sourcing school cafeterias, the Good Food Box, and the Student Nutrition Program from local foods would provide farmers with a consistent market, and would benefit the whole community. If the government runs it, they can write by-laws enforcing the 25% local food purchasing, which would encourage Food Service Providers (like Gordon's Foods) to purchase local produce.

Always should be addressed in school.Current model could use consistent funding and financial support from local school boards or the ministry.We need a way of getting the Community Health Department to work with the Planners and Cultural Services and the School boards in order to keep providing these kinds of programs. Always awesome.People are afraid of vandalism, of looking messy, of it not being cared for. Those are all reasonable fears. It depends if I could do most of my shopping there! I have a local grocery store outside of Sarnia, and it does really well. Since I hate grocery shopping, I like something that is interesting (Costco), but I do want to support local too (Foodland, and farm gate stores). Can I buy toilet paper there? Can I get orange juice or a cool facsimile? Is the produce amazing? Are the meats cut well and reasonably priced? Good loss leader sales will always get me in the door.

Schools and daycares can offer fresh, locally grown food at low or no cost to students. Research has shown that students are more attentive and learn better when they are fed.More education to dispel the myth that healthy eating is expensive. Make buying junk food a dis-incentive; junk food costs less but has fewer nutrients.More support for resources such as the mobile market so that food is accessible in all neighbourhoods, especially around schools.Have farm stands at libraries or community centres. Make quality food boxes (produce, snacks, basic foods) available to families at a good rate (include delivery). An expanded Garden Fresh Box/produce box, and like a Christmas hamper but available monthly.Incentives for big chain stores to carry locally grown foods.Incentives for every convenience store to have a farm stand section.Ensure that travelling to a grocery store is not a hardship - there are high risk low income neighbourhoods that don't have grocery stores that are accessible.
